Scenarios.Name: Welcome back!
Scenarios.Title: Welcome back!
Scenarios.Question: Welcome back to MindTrails! Let’s get started with practicing flexible thinking. Today, you will: answer a few questions about your anxiety, complete 3 scenarios that challenge you to come up with thoughts, feelings, and behaviors, and wrap-up with a Quick Thinking exercise.

Scenarios.Name: Three Brief Questions
Scenarios.Title: Three Brief Questions
Scenarios.Question: Thinking about the last 24 hours, how anxious have you felt? 0 = Most calm I could imagine being 10 = Most anxious, panicked, or scared I could imagine being

Scenarios.Name: Three Brief Questions
Scenarios.Title: Three Brief Questions
Scenarios.Question: Thinking about the last 24 hours, how much were you able to change the way you thought about things when you wanted to feel better.(An example might be: If you were feeling worried about an upcoming test, were you able to think about how much you studied, so that you felt less worried?) 0 = Not at all – I wasn’t able to think in different ways to feel better 10 = Completely– I was totally able to think in different ways to feel better I didn’t want/need to change how I was feeling I’m not sure, or I wasn’t paying attention to my feeling

Scenarios.Name: Three Brief Questions
Scenarios.Title: Three Brief Questions
Scenarios.Question: Thinking about the last 24 hours, how much did you try to stay away from or be less involved in situations that would make you anxious or scared?(An example might be: If your teacher asked a question to the class and you knew the answer, do you not answer so you won’t draw attention to yourself?) 0 = I tried to stay away from doing anything and everything that would make me anxious or scared 10 = If there was something that would make me anxious or scared, I pushed myself to do it anyway I didn’t have anything that would make me anxious or scared in the last 24 hours

Scenarios.Name: Three Brief Questions
Scenarios.Title: Three Brief Questions
Scenarios.Question: Thank you!

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: In this exercise, please think of an UPCOMING situation that you expect will make you feel anxious, worried, or scared.

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: Pick a situation that you worry might go badly, or that you expect will bring on feelings of anxiety (like racing heart, sweating). Any situation that will make you feel quite anxious or scared will work, as long as it is a situation that is likely to actually happen.

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: Please describe the situation in a few words:

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: Please imagine the situation as vividly as possible (i.e., so that it feels very real).Try to imagine you are actually in the situation. Play out the specific parts of the situation in your head. Try to imagine using all your senses while you think about this situation. Think about the things you would see, hear, and smell if you were really in that situation. Think about the kinds of things you would think or feel if you were actually there. Please click the NEXT button and play this situation in your head for the next 20 seconds.

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: How anxious did you feel (at the highest level of anxiety) as you completed the imagery task? Press on the bar to see the slider.

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: How vividly did you imagine the situation?
Words: Not at all vivid
Somewhat vivid
Moderately vivid
Very vivid
Totally vivid
Prefer not to answer

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: How likely is it that the situation or task will turn out well versus turn out badly?
Words: Very likely to turn out well
Somewhat likely to turn out well
Neutral
Somewhat likely to turn out badly
Very likely to turn out badly
Prefer not to answer

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: If this situation did turn out badly, how well or badly would you be able to handle it?
Words: Very well
Somewhat well
Neutral
Somewhat badly
Very badly
Prefer not to answer

Description: You have a science test next week that's going to count for a lot of your grade. You haven't understood this unit's course material that well and you wonder how the test is going to go.
Scenarios.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.
Words: Important test
This test will go well.
I can ask for help to study for this test.
My teacher will think I'm dumb if I do not do well.
I think that I may never catch on, but know that if I try, I'll be able to.
This class is so hard to keep up in, but decide to try a little harder.
I feel excited to prove myself wrong.
I feel ready to get going with studying.
I am worried about taking this test and failing.
I'm worried about asking for help to study, but know that it'll help me get a better grade.
I am scared about failing, but know that trying is what matters.
I'll study really hard and ask my teacher for help if I need to.
I'll ask my friends in the class questions if I don't understand something.
I'll pretend to be sick on the day of the class so I don't have to take the test.
I don't want to tell my parents about how difficult this class is, but decide to tell them anyways.
I really don't want to study, but I know it will pay off on the test.
Scenarios.Question: N/A

Description: During tonight's parent-teacher conference, your guardian is going to talk to your math teacher. You're not doing well in math, and you haven't told your guardian this yet.
Scenarios.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.
Words: Not doing well in math
I have been trying really hard in that class.
My guardian will be proud of me that I'm trying hard.
My teacher will tell my parents I am not doing well.
My guardian may be upset, but that is something that I can understand.
My parents will think I need some extra help, and I am okay with that.
I feel happy that my guardian gets to learn about my progress.
I'm feeling calm knowing that my guardian will accept me no matter what.
I am nervous that my guardian will be let down by my progress.
I feel embarrassed that my guardian will learn about my lack of progress, but decide it is best for them to know.
I feel bad that I am a bit behind, but realize these things happen.
I take some deep breaths while my guardian is talking to my teacher.
I'll ask my guardian for advice.
I'll blame my grades on my teacher.
I will want to get upset, but decide to keep calm when my guardian gets home.
I may want to give up on math, but decide to keep trying because I need to pass this class.
Scenarios.Question: N/A

Description: You are meeting with your teacher. To make it on-time, you just walked up two flights of stairs quickly, and feel your heart beating very rapidly.
Scenarios.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.
Words: Walking up stairs
I am excited for the meeting.
I made it up those stairs really quickly.
Am I having a heart attack?
I wonder about all the reasons I could be so out of breath, but decide it is normal when rushing to a meeting.
I wonder if my teacher will notice how out of breath I am, but decide it is okay if she does notice.
I'm happy I made the meeting on time.
I'm feeling excited now that my blood is pumping.
I'm worried that there's something really wrong with me.
I feel embarrassed about being out of breath, but decide to listen to what my teacher has to say.
I'm panicking a little about whether I'm going to be ok, but remind myself that it's normal to feel out of breath after walking up a bunch of stairs.
I take a few deep breaths.
I take a few sips from my water bottle.
I start looking up symptoms of a heart attack online to see if I'm dying.
I feel the urge to tell my teacher that something's really wrong with me, but remind myself that I'm actually OK.
I tell myself that I'm so nervous about this meeting that my heart is beating quickly, but remind myself that it's actually just my body's reaction to coming up the stairs quickly.
Scenarios.Question: N/A

Scenarios.Name: Quick Thinking
Scenarios.Title: Quick Thinking
Scenarios.Description: On the next screen, you’ll see a situation that might make someone nervous, worried, scared, or anxious. Here’s an example: You’re out with friends and receive this message from your parent saying, “You need to come home right now.

Scenarios.Name: Quick Thinking
Scenarios.Title: Quick Thinking
Scenarios.Description: In the text box, please write as many different thoughts that might come to your mind in that moment. You’ll have 60 seconds to do this. For this example, you might write: What did I do wrong? My parent has something really important to tell me. I’m really tired, so I’m glad to be going home.

Scenarios.Name: Quick Thinking
Scenarios.Title: Quick Thinking
Scenarios.Description: You don’t need to write full sentences, and you should push yourself to write as many different thoughts as possible! These can be a mix of positive and negative thoughts. To add another thought, press the “Submit” button on your screen.

Scenarios.Name: Quick Thinking
Scenarios.Title: Quick Thinking
Scenarios.Description: You overhear some classmates talking about a party tonight that you didn’t know about.
How likely is it that the situation or task will turn out well versus turn out badly?

Somewhat likely to turn out well

Somewhat well

Description: You and your friends are shopping at the mall. You go to the food court and get slushies, and accidentally spill your red slushie down the front of your new white shirt.
Scenarios.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.
Words: Spilled slushie
I think about how many people this has probably happened to.
I think about how my parents will get a kick out of this.
I think I will look sloppy in front of my friends.
It feels like my friends are judging me, but decide they probably don't really care.
I am getting a lot of stares, but it could be that they think the slushie looks good.
I feel lucky I didn't drop the whole slushie.
I'm confident my parent will be able to get the stain out.
I feel like a fool and want to say sorry.
I'm mad that I wasted my money, but know that I'll be ok.
I'm embarrassed that I have this huge stain on my white shirt, but probably no one else cares.
I laugh with my friends about my spill.
I clean up and keep shopping.
I stay silent the rest of the time we're shopping.
I want to go home, but stay at the mall.
I feel like crying, but take a deep breath and keep shopping with my friends.
Scenarios.Question: N/A

Description: You are at a quiet restaurant with a lot of your family members for dinner. While taking a drink of your water, you accidently drop the glass on the floor and it shatters.
Scenarios.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.
Words: Shattered glass
I think about how everyone sometimes has clumsy moments.
People in my family have dropped stuff at restaurants in the past.
I have to be an embarrassment.
The waiter will be irritated, but I'll apologize and offer to help clean up.
I think about how my family may be annoyed, but I can handle that.
I'm able to stay calm.
I'm happy that the waiter doesn't seem to mind that much.
I have a knot in my stomach after the whole restaurant looked at me.
I'm embarrassed that I dropped the glass, but know that people drop things all of the time.
I feel bad, but remind myself that I'll forget about this in a few days.
I offer to leave extra money for the tip.
I offer to do extra chores at home, so money can be left to replace the glass.
I cry because I feel terrible.
I want to never come back to the restaurant, but will say yes to coming back if my family wants to come back.
I want to cry, but decide that would not be helpful.
Scenarios.Question: N/A

Description: You met a cute peer in one of your classes. After school, you notice that they started following you.
Scenarios.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.
Words: Cute peer on social media
I think they want to get to know me.
I think it's flattering.
They're probably making fun of my pictures.
I bet they'll stop following me after they see what I post. But, they probably won't actually unfollow me.
I think they may not like my profile, but decide they probably won't put that much thought into it.
I feel flattered that they wanted to follow me.
I feel energized by the add.
I wonder if the add was an accident.
I feel curious about the reason they added me, but realize it is just because they wanted to.
I feel worried about what they think of me, but know that I can deal with not knowing.
I add more fun pictures.
I talk to my mom about how excited I am.
I unfollow the people that they might not like.
I want to message them and ask about the add, but decide to not put much thought into the add.
I want to gossip about the add to my friends, but decide to stay modest.
Scenarios.Question: N/A

Description: You are meeting with your teacher. To make it on-time, you just walked up two flights of stairs quickly, and feel your heart beating very rapidly.
Scenarios.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.
Words: Walking up stairs
I am excited for the meeting.
I made it up those stairs really quickly.
Am I having a heart attack?
I wonder about all the reasons I could be so out of breath, but decide it is normal when rushing to a meeting.
I wonder if my teacher will notice how out of breath I am, but decide it is okay if she does notice.
I'm happy I made the meeting on time.
I'm feeling excited now that my blood is pumping.
I'm worried that there's something really wrong with me.
I feel embarrassed about being out of breath, but decide to listen to what my teacher has to say.
I'm panicking a little about whether I'm going to be ok, but remind myself that it's normal to feel out of breath after walking up a bunch of stairs.
I take a few deep breaths.
I take a few sips from my water bottle.
I start looking up symptoms of a heart attack online to see if I'm dying.
I feel the urge to tell my teacher that something's really wrong with me, but remind myself that I'm actually OK.
I tell myself that I'm so nervous about this meeting that my heart is beating quickly, but remind myself that it's actually just my body's reaction to coming up the stairs quickly.
Scenarios.Question: N/A

Description: You have to give a presentation in your international language class today. When you stand up in front of the class, you feel your cheeks get hot and your hands start to tremble.
Scenarios.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.
Words: Presentation in class
It's normal to feel a little warm when you're anxious about presenting.
I've done everything I can to prepare for this presentation.
Everyone will see that my hands are shaking.
I want to sit back down, but instead go forward with the presentation.
I want to cover my face, but stand up tall and present anyway.
I'm relieved to get this presentation over with.
I'm happy with how much I've prepared for this presentation.
I'm worried that I'm going to pass out.
I'm nervous that people can see my hands shaking, but they probably won't be able to see from where they're sitting.
I'm scared that my cheeks feeling hot means that I'm going to faint, but I'll probably be OK and this feeling will pass.
I smile at the class and start my presentation.
I speak with a strong tone.
I ask the teacher if I can present another day.
I want to go to the bathroom and splash my face with water, but decide to power through.
I consider pretending that I'm sick so I don't have to present, but challenge myself to give the presentation anyway.
Scenarios.Question: N/A

Description: Your friend is having a huge birthday party and most of the people in your grade will be there. You know you can't afford a gift for your friend.
Scenarios.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.
Words: Can't afford a gift
It'll be good to see lots of the people in my grade.
My friend will be happy that I'm able to go.
My friend will be embarrassed to have me because I don't have a gift.
I think about how I should've brought a gift, but know that my friend is glad I'm there.
If people judge me for not bringing a gift, I'll still have a good time at the party.
I feel happy to be around all of my friends.
I feel enthusiastic about sharing my good energy.
I feel guilty for not bringing a present.
I feel bad, but decide the party will go on.
I'm a little sick to my stomach thinking about not being able to afford a gift, but remind myself that my friend won't judge me.
I have fun dancing at the party.
I smile at all of my friends.
I try to sneak by my friend so they don't notice I don't have a gift when I walk in.
I'm tempted to leave before the presents are opened, but remind myself that I'm actually having fun.
I want to skip the party so I don't have to think about not being able to afford the present, but decide to push myself to go anyway. I know I'll have a good time.
Scenarios.Question: N/A

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: Pick a situation that you worry might go badly, or that you expect will bring on feelings of anxiety (like racing heart, sweating). Any situation that will make you feel quite anxious or scared will work, as long as it is a situation that is likely to actually happen.

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: Please describe the situation in a few words:

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: Please imagine the situation as vividly as possible (i.e., so that it feels very real).Try to imagine you are actually in the situation. Play out the specific parts of the situation in your head. Try to imagine using all your senses while you think about this situation. Think about the things you would see, hear, and smell if you were really in that situation. Think about the kinds of things you would think or feel if you were actually there. Please click the NEXT button and play this situation in your head for the next 20 seconds.

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: How anxious did you feel (at the highest level of anxiety) as you completed the imagery task? Press on the bar to see the slider.

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: How vividly did you imagine the situation?
Words: Not at all vivid
Somewhat vivid
Moderately vivid
Very vivid
Totally vivid
Prefer not to answer

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: How likely is it that the situation or task will turn out well versus turn out badly?
Words: Very likely to turn out well
Somewhat likely to turn out well
Neutral
Somewhat likely to turn out badly
Very likely to turn out badly
Prefer not to answer

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: If this situation did turn out badly, how well or badly would you be able to handle it?
Words: Very well
Somewhat well
Neutral
Somewhat badly
Very badly
Prefer not to answer

Description: You met a cute peer in one of your classes. After school, you notice that they started following you.
Scenarios.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.
Words: Cute peer on social media
I think they want to get to know me.
I think it's flattering.
They're probably making fun of my pictures.
I bet they'll stop following me after they see what I post. But, they probably won't actually unfollow me.
I think they may not like my profile, but decide they probably won't put that much thought into it.
I feel flattered that they wanted to follow me.
I feel energized by the add.
I wonder if the add was an accident.
I feel curious about the reason they added me, but realize it is just because they wanted to.
I feel worried about what they think of me, but know that I can deal with not knowing.
I add more fun pictures.
I talk to my mom about how excited I am.
I unfollow the people that they might not like.
I want to message them and ask about the add, but decide to not put much thought into the add.
I want to gossip about the add to my friends, but decide to stay modest.
Scenarios.Question: N/A

Description: You post something different from what you normally post. After a couple of hours, you only have about half the number of likes on your post compared to what you normally have.
Scenarios.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.
Words: Not a lot of likes
People must not be online right now.
My followers may be waiting to see what I post next.
People think my post is dumb.
Others may not like my new post, but I do and that's what counts.
Even if no one likes what I posted, I do, and that's what's important.
I'm confident that others will eventually like the new post.
I feel good about my the post.
I'll never try different styles of posts again.
I feel sad that I didn't get more likes, but am able to accept that.
I feel uncomfortable not knowing why I didn't receive a lot of likes, but am okay not knowing.
I keep posting things I want to post.
I decide to stay in a good mood about my post.
I get frustrated and take down my post.
I want to ask my friends why they think I didn't get more likes, but decide to move on.
I feel like taking down my account for a while, but keep it up instead.
Scenarios.Question: N/A

Description: As you're getting into the shower, you see a huge spider on the wall. You turn away for a second and look back and realize it's gone.
Scenarios.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.
Words: Missing spider
I'm glad it's gone.
I think it went back to it's home.
It's going to crawl on me!
I think about how it could bite me, but decide it probably won't.
I think about how it could be venomous, but realize the chances of that are slim.
I'm curious where it went.
I'm calm as I get into the shower.
I'm scared the spider will show up when I least expect it.
I'm anxious about getting into the shower, but know I can overcome my fear.
I'm grossed out, but remind myself that the spider probably can't hurt me.
I decide to turn the water on.
I start to play some music.
I scream and run away.
I want to call someone to help me find the spider, but decide to just take my shower.
I want to spray bug spray everywhere, but decide to go about my bathroom routine.
Scenarios.Question: N/A

Scenarios.Name: Quick Thinking
Scenarios.Title: Quick Thinking
Scenarios.Description: On the next screen, you’ll see a situation that might make someone nervous, worried, scared, or anxious. Here’s an example: You’re out with friends and receive this message from your parent saying, “You need to come home right now.

Scenarios.Name: Quick Thinking
Scenarios.Title: Quick Thinking
Scenarios.Description: In the text box, please write as many different thoughts that might come to your mind in that moment. You’ll have 60 seconds to do this. For this example, you might write: What did I do wrong? My parent has something really important to tell me. I’m really tired, so I’m glad to be going home.

Scenarios.Name: Quick Thinking
Scenarios.Title: Quick Thinking
Scenarios.Description: You don’t need to write full sentences, and you should push yourself to write as many different thoughts as possible! These can be a mix of positive and negative thoughts. To add another thought, press the “Submit” button on your screen.

Scenarios.Name: Quick Thinking
Scenarios.Title: Quick Thinking
Scenarios.Description: You overhear some classmates talking about a party tonight that you didn’t know about.
How likely is it that the situation or task will turn out well versus turn out badly?

Scenarios.Name: Welcome back!
Scenarios.Title: Welcome back!
Scenarios.Question: Welcome back to MindTrails! Let’s get started with practicing flexible thinking. Today, you will: answer a few questions about your anxiety, complete 3 scenarios that challenge you to come up with thoughts, feelings, and behaviors, and wrap-up with a Quick Thinking exercise.

Scenarios.Name: Three Brief Questions
Scenarios.Title: Three Brief Questions
Scenarios.Question: Thinking about the last 24 hours, how anxious have you felt? 0 = Most calm I could imagine being 10 = Most anxious, panicked, or scared I could imagine being

Scenarios.Name: Three Brief Questions
Scenarios.Title: Three Brief Questions
Scenarios.Question: Thinking about the last 24 hours, how much were you able to change the way you thought about things when you wanted to feel better.(An example might be: If you were feeling worried about an upcoming test, were you able to think about how much you studied, so that you felt less worried?) 0 = Not at all – I wasn’t able to think in different ways to feel better 10 = Completely– I was totally able to think in different ways to feel better I didn’t want/need to change how I was feeling I’m not sure, or I wasn’t paying attention to my feeling

Scenarios.Name: Three Brief Questions
Scenarios.Title: Three Brief Questions
Scenarios.Question: Thinking about the last 24 hours, how much did you try to stay away from or be less involved in situations that would make you anxious or scared?(An example might be: If your teacher asked a question to the class and you knew the answer, do you not answer so you won’t draw attention to yourself?) 0 = I tried to stay away from doing anything and everything that would make me anxious or scared 10 = If there was something that would make me anxious or scared, I pushed myself to do it anyway I didn’t have anything that would make me anxious or scared in the last 24 hours

Scenarios.Name: Three Brief Questions
Scenarios.Title: Three Brief Questions
Scenarios.Question: Thank you!

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: In this exercise, please think of an UPCOMING situation that you expect will make you feel anxious, worried, or scared.

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: Pick a situation that you worry might go badly, or that you expect will bring on feelings of anxiety (like racing heart, sweating). Any situation that will make you feel quite anxious or scared will work, as long as it is a situation that is likely to actually happen.

Play out the specific parts of the situation in your head. Try to imagine using all your senses while you think about this situation. Think about the things you would see, hear, and smell if you were really in that situation. Think about the kinds of things you would think or feel if you were actually there. Please click the NEXT button and play this situation in your head for the next 20 seconds.

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: How anxious did you feel (at the highest level of anxiety) as you completed the imagery task? Press on the bar to see the slider.

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: How vividly did you imagine the situation?
Words: Not at all vivid
Somewhat vivid
Moderately vivid
Very vivid
Totally vivid
Prefer not to answer

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: How likely is it that the situation or task will turn out well versus turn out badly?
Words: Very likely to turn out well
Somewhat likely to turn out well
Neutral
Somewhat likely to turn out badly
Very likely to turn out badly
Prefer not to answer

Scenarios.Name: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Title: Using Your Imagination
Scenarios.Question: If this situation did turn out badly, how well or badly would you be able to handle it?
Words: Very well
Somewhat well
Neutral
Somewhat badly
Very badly
Prefer not to answer

Description: Your friend is having a huge birthday party and most of the people in your grade will be there. You know you can't afford a gift for your friend.
Scenarios.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.
Words: Can't afford a gift
It'll be good to see lots of the people in my grade.
My friend will be happy that I'm able to go.
My friend will be embarrassed to have me because I don't have a gift.
I think about how I should've brought a gift, but know that my friend is glad I'm there.
If people judge me for not bringing a gift, I'll still have a good time at the party.
I feel happy to be around all of my friends.
I feel enthusiastic about sharing my good energy.
I feel guilty for not bringing a present.
I feel bad, but decide the party will go on.
I'm a little sick to my stomach thinking about not being able to afford a gift, but remind myself that my friend won't judge me.
I have fun dancing at the party.
I smile at all of my friends.
I try to sneak by my friend so they don't notice I don't have a gift when I walk in.
I'm tempted to leave before the presents are opened, but remind myself that I'm actually having fun.
I want to skip the party so I don't have to think about not being able to afford the present, but decide to push myself to go anyway. I know I'll have a good time.
Scenarios.Question: N/A

Description: You notice your parents are upset with each other. They give you a short answer when you try to talk with them.
Scenarios.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.
Words: Upset parents
They'll be over this in a few days.
I think about how they will be in a better mood later.
I immediately blame myself for their fight.
I wonder how long this argument will last, and remind myself that I can't control what they do.
I think about how they might continue to get more upset, then I think about how they will calm down with time.
I feel calm even though they're a little upset.
I'm glad that I don't have to help them feel better in this moment.
I'm anxious about the tension between them.
I feel guilty, but realize that I did nothing wrong.
I feel worried about my parents, but remind myself that I don't have to help them get along.
I go do something that distracts me from the situation.
I call my friends and we talk about what happened in school.
I tell them that they're being selfish.
I go for a walk outside and remind myself that they'll be OK soon.
I want to mention that I feel they are making me feel bad, but I write about it instead.
Scenarios.Question: N/A

Description: You have a science test next week that's going to count for a lot of your grade. You haven't understood this unit's course material that well and you wonder how the test is going to go.
Scenarios.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.
Words: Important test
This test will go well.
I can ask for help to study for this test.
My teacher will think I'm dumb if I do not do well.
I think that I may never catch on, but know that if I try, I'll be able to.
This class is so hard to keep up in, but decide to try a little harder.
I feel excited to prove myself wrong.
I feel ready to get going with studying.
I am worried about taking this test and failing.
I'm worried about asking for help to study, but know that it'll help me get a better grade.
I am scared about failing, but know that trying is what matters.
I'll study really hard and ask my teacher for help if I need to.
I'll ask my friends in the class questions if I don't understand something.
I'll pretend to be sick on the day of the class so I don't have to take the test.
I don't want to tell my parents about how difficult this class is, but decide to tell them anyways.
I really don't want to study, but I know it will pay off on the test.
Scenarios.Question: N/A

Description: As you're getting into the shower, you see a huge spider on the wall. You turn away for a second and look back and realize it's gone.
Scenarios.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.
Words: Missing spider
I'm glad it's gone.
I think it went back to it's home.
It's going to crawl on me!
I think about how it could bite me, but decide it probably won't.
I think about how it could be venomous, but realize the chances of that are slim.
I'm curious where it went.
I'm calm as I get into the shower.
I'm scared the spider will show up when I least expect it.
I'm anxious about getting into the shower, but know I can overcome my fear.
I'm grossed out, but remind myself that the spider probably can't hurt me.
I decide to turn the water on.
I start to play some music.
I scream and run away.
I want to call someone to help me find the spider, but decide to just take my shower.
I want to spray bug spray everywhere, but decide to go about my bathroom routine.
Scenarios.Question: N/A

Description: You and your family are heading out of town for a few days and your parent asks you to double-check that all the appliances in your house are turned off before you leave. You had to rush to pack so didn't get to check everything.
Scenarios.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.
Words: Turned off appliances
I think about how everything is fine.
I think about how I could mention the situation to my family and all will be okay.
I think about how something bad may happen because I didn't get to check the appliances properly.
I think about how upset my family will be with me, but know that they will understand.
Our house is really safe, and our fire alarm would alert any neighbors if there was actually a problem.
I am satisfied that I checked the appliances that I could on my way out.
I feel calm now that I'm in the car and on my way out of town with my family.
I'm scared that our house is going to burn down.
I'm miserable worrying about whether everything is off, but remind myself to focus on the present and take a deep breath.
I feel worried about the house burning down, but know that I can tolerate this feeling and it will pass.
I'll remember to ask for help to check the appliances in the future if I am running out of time before we need to go.
I'll remember that I don't have to check all of the appliances multiple times before we leave.
I focus on everything that could go wrong because I didn't have time to check.
I want to ask my family to turn around so I can go double-check all of the appliances. But, I know that I can tolerate the feelings of anxiety and these feelings will pass.
I want to be upset about the situation, but decide to chat with my family.
Scenarios.Question: N/A

Description: You and your friends are shopping at the mall. You go to the food court and get slushies, and accidentally spill your red slushie down the front of your new white shirt.
Scenarios.IncorrectFeedback: Whoops! That doesn't look right. Please wait a moment and try again.
Words: Spilled slushie
I think about how many people this has probably happened to.
I think about how my parents will get a kick out of this.
I think I will look sloppy in front of my friends.
It feels like my friends are judging me, but decide they probably don't really care.
I am getting a lot of stares, but it could be that they think the slushie looks good.
I feel lucky I didn't drop the whole slushie.
I'm confident my parent will be able to get the stain out.
I feel like a fool and want to say sorry.
I'm mad that I wasted my money, but know that I'll be ok.
I'm embarrassed that I have this huge stain on my white shirt, but probably no one else cares.
I laugh with my friends about my spill.
I clean up and keep shopping.
I stay silent the rest of the time we're shopping.
I want to go home, but stay at the mall.
I feel like crying, but take a deep breath and keep shopping with my friends.
Scenarios.Question: N/A
